stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates Biobak’s rework of Course 1 in preparation for a one-level demo, focusing on N64-accurate render-order/layer fixes, performance benchmarking on real hardware (including X3 microcode comparisons), and importing/triaging a batch of updated actors (Yoshi egg, Goomba King, Spike Goomba, bouncy flower, bunny Goomba, etc.). He also prototypes a new “infinitely far” background and a camera-reactive sun/lens-flare effect, and briefly explains his custom Mario nose “physics bone” system.
stream_context.significance_reason: Course 1 is being brought up to demo-ready quality: major visual integration work (render layers, alpha/coverage bugs), verified performance on real N64 hardware, and the first pass of importing a large set of refreshed actors from Biobak.

findings.summary: The upcoming demo release is planned to be only a single stage (Course 1), and the stream’s goal is to get the Course 1 rework integrated enough to start moving toward that demo.
findings.quote: The demo will just be one stage, nothing more.

findings.summary: A central integration problem is N64 render order: Kaze tries to move as much geometry as possible into “layout 0” while preserving correct overdraw behavior, repeatedly re-sorting meshes and materials to avoid elements incorrectly drawing in front/behind each other.

Kaze benchmarks the reworked Course 1 scene and confirms it runs on real N64 at close to 60 FPS in the tested segment; he notes large CPU idle time in profiling, implying the scene is not CPU-bound and still has headroom even before adding new actors.
findings.quote: It actually runs on the N64 console. It doesn't just run, dude, it runs at like nearly 60 FPS still.

findings.summary: He highlights that X3 (microcode/renderer mode) can be faster due to a larger vertex buffer, but warns that emulator/PC benchmarks can be misleading compared to real-console testing.

A visible rendering bug (stripes/alpha artifacts) is traced to incorrect alpha/coverage settings (e.g., accidental alpha-compare/coverage mode choices). After adjusting coverage behavior, the artifact disappears and RDP cost drops slightly.

ROM size becomes a live constraint: his build is around ~63 MB and he discusses 64 MB as a practical N64 boundary; he argues that exceeding 64 MB feels like “cheating” even if it still runs on hardware (while acknowledging larger sizes are technically possible in some contexts).
findings.quote: If you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game? ... It just feels like cheating to me.

findings.summary: At Biobak’s request, Course 1 is shifted to use an “infinitely far” background rather than keeping the whole level visually nearby, improving the sense of scale; Kaze implements it and then tweaks cloud/sun placement, noting Biobak may disagree with his vertical positioning changes.

Kaze prototypes a camera-reactive sun/lens flare effect intended to feel blinding when looking upward; he chooses a UV-based solution (adjusting texture coordinates) over rotating a geometry/texture plane because rotating planes would be too expensive on N64.
findings.quote: That's so expensive! I'm not rotating a whole texture plane.

findings.summary: He explains his Mario nose jiggle as a custom “physics bone” system that stores prior-frame nose position, derives acceleration, converts it into yaw/pitch, and applies pendulum-style integration; it’s described as hyper-optimized and fragile (small changes risk crashes).
findings.quote: This is hyper-optimized. If you make one change to this, it's just gonna crash.

findings.summary: While importing Biobak’s updated Yoshi egg actor, Kaze notes a pipeline limitation: certain lighting-color setups that look good in Blender are not viable in-game, so the team must approximate the look using prim/env color tricks (and he plans to revisit full import/programming later).

Importing updated Goomba-family actors reveals a common pitfall: billboard bones don’t inherit parent rotation the way the modeler expected because they use the billboard matrix, forcing Kaze to re-center/adjust the rig and animation alignment.
findings.quote: It doesn't copy the rotation of the parent object. Because it copies the rotation from the billboard matrix.

findings.summary: Kaze plans a gameplay adjustment for the Goomba King encounter: the fight will change, especially how the boss moves around level geometry, and he urges viewers not to judge the current behavior as final during the import phase.
findings.quote: We're gonna change the Goombas fight a little bit though. So don't worry if you think it sucks right now.

findings.summary: Kaze explicitly frames his streaming approach as “minimum effort”: he streams to get feedback and share progress, not to operate as a professional content creator, and he resists additional editorial/organizational work (like extensive playlist curation).
findings.quote: You need to realize my streams is like minimum effort... I will not do anything except the bare minimum.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivered the Course 1 visual rework that Kaze is integrating for the demo, triggering the render-order/layer cleanup and the subsequent pass on collisions and actor imports.

Biobak requested a change in environmental presentation: swap from a nearby full-level view to an “infinitely far” background for Course 1, which Kaze implements while negotiating taste differences (cloud height, sun placement).

Biobak supplies a large set of actor updates with explicit optimization notes (fewer materials/bones/triangles, rescaled assets, removed hidden geometry, etc.), but some rigs/Blender exports don’t translate cleanly into the in-game pipeline and need Kaze-side fixes.

badub.summary: Kaze previews new music from Badub and notes at least one track is authored with variants for each biome, supporting the project’s plan for smooth, context-sensitive musical transitions within levels.
badub.quote: This song has versions for every biome.

findings.summary: Lilaa participates in performance/rendering discussion (including benchmark/setup confusion around X3 and repo settings), acting as a recurring technical sounding board even when Kaze rejects specific suggestions as misunderstandings.

key_stories.title: Course 1 rework integration: render layers, alpha/coverage bugs, and real-N64 performance
key_stories.summary: While integrating Biobak’s Course 1 rework for the demo, Kaze runs into classic N64 constraints: render order, layer conflicts, and alpha/coverage configuration causing visible artifacts. The arc matters because it shows the project’s core ethos—art upgrades must survive real hardware rules, not just emulator visuals.
key_stories.challenge: Imported rework looks wrong in places due to draw order/layering and an alpha/coverage bug; performance readouts are noisy and misleading until tested correctly.
key_stories.process: Kaze moves geometry into appropriate layouts, reorders display/draw order, audits render modes, fixes coverage/alpha-compare settings, and then benchmarks both in emulator settings and on real N64 (including switching to X3 for a more accurate/faster configuration).
key_stories.outcome: Major artifact (stripe/alpha issue) is removed, RDP cost drops slightly, and the scene is confirmed running close to 60 FPS on real N64 in the tested segment—supporting feasibility for a demo-quality Course 1.
key_stories.key_quote: It actually runs on the N64 console. It doesn't just run, dude, it runs at like nearly 60 FPS still.

key_stories.title: Making the sky feel bigger: infinite background and a camera-reactive sun
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements Biobak’s request for an “infinitely far” background to improve sense of scale, then adds a sun flare that reacts to camera orientation. This story shows how the team pursues modern-looking atmosphere while staying inside N64 performance and texture constraints.
key_stories.challenge: The original background presentation makes the level feel too “nearby,” and the sun/flare behavior needs to look convincing without expensive geometry transforms; texture clamping/mirroring introduces unexpected artifacts.
key_stories.process: Kaze swaps in an infinite background setup, tunes cloud/sun vertical placement, then prototypes sun rotation by manipulating UVs (avoiding rotating planes). He iterates through clamping/mirroring settings and export mistakes until the artifacting is acceptable.
key_stories.outcome: The scene gains a stronger “look up and get blinded” effect, and the background reads as more distant—though Kaze notes it’s still not perfectly matching Biobak’s preference and will need further polish.
key_stories.key_quote: That's so expensive! I'm not rotating a whole texture plane.

key_stories.title: Actor refresh meets engine reality: billboard bones and mismatched animations
key_stories.summary: When importing refreshed enemy models, Kaze discovers rig assumptions that break in-engine, especially around billboard bones and animation alignment. The story matters because it illustrates the hidden integration labor behind ‘just updating models’ for an N64 pipeline.
key_stories.challenge: Updated Goomba-related actors look wrong due to billboard matrix behavior and rig/roll mistakes; animation files no longer match behavior after adjustments.
key_stories.process: Kaze diagnoses that billboard bones don’t inherit rotation from the parent, re-centers/offsets the rig, repairs roll/armature issues, adds needed bones/shadows, and notes which fixes will be done off-stream.
key_stories.outcome: The actors look substantially better, but Kaze logs remaining work (notably Spike Goomba animation/ground clipping) and accepts temporary behavior-animation mismatch to keep progress moving toward the demo.
key_stories.key_quote: It doesn't copy the rotation of the parent object. Because it copies the rotation from the billboard matrix.
